text: /// I may open up more about that soon, but for now, please know that this story has played a big part in my journey, and I don’t think I would have made it this far, or had the courage to get the care I need, without you loyal readers. From the bottom of my heart, Thank You. https://t.co/h9V9LqJ8sR
/// I’m working on making peace with that information, and remembering how to take myself a little less seriously and just have fun in the fandom again.

/// As of this Monday - when I had my account deactivated briefly - I was finally getting some answers, and in my fear and shame over it all, I was ready to leave this story behind, a single update from the end.

/// And over the course of writing this, I have been dealing with my own much less clear cut hearing problems of my own, and without solid answers, I’ve been even more emotional about the content, while being unsure of my “place” as I wrote it.

/// …but the love and support you readers have shown me as I shared this story - and even my doubts as I wrote it - truly means the world to me. This tale comes from a really raw and vulnerable place for me. I don’t think it’s any secret that there’s a lot of me in this story.

/// thank you with all my heart to everyone who read and supported this story, especially those of you who stuck with it - and me! - all the way to the end. I know it’s been a rough ride at times, with long waits between updates and more than one emotional breakdown on my end…

And once again, Eijirou Kirishima was a ray of sunshine.

Raising three deaf children was sure to be the challenge of a lifetime, but he couldn’t ask for a better team to raise them with. Katsuki was his full moon in the dark, and Shizuko the brightest star he’d ever seen, beaming her starlight on the brand new stars just beginning.
A peace Eijirou had been missing for years filled his core as he cradled the newborn baby and relaxed into the comfort of Katsuki’s strong arms and Shizuko’s little ones.

Hands and faces washed, teeth brushed, and snuggled into their coziest pajamas, Eijirou and Katsuki climbed gingerly into bed, each with a newborn in their arms. Shizuko climbed up in between then and wrapped her arms her dads, gazing at the babies.
Eijirou knew the only thing she’d miss by “sleeping” with them was sleep, but he didn’t mind. “If you promise to be careful, I’ll show you how to feed them.”
“Can I sleep with you tonight?” Shizuko wanted to know as Eijirou and Katsuki each changed a diaper and dressed the babies for bed. “I don’t want to miss /anything/!”

It was an intense adjustment, going from being a parent of one to a parent of three, especially when the two new ones were a mere five pounds each and so delicate, but every glance at the babies made Eijirou’s soul swell with a love he’d never known was possible.
/Congratulations,/ Katsuki signed to her. /You just became a big sister./“I love being a big sister!!”

“THE BABIES ARE HERE, THE BABIES ARE HERE!” Shizuko cried as she climbed into the car, holding her hands behind her back to remind herself not to touch them until they were home and she had washed her hands. “Ohhhhh…. They’re SO CUTE!”
@NotZombrigit TOLD YA I HAD A HECK OF AN ENDING PLANNED 🥰🥰

“They’re perfect,” he breathed, looking over them one more time before starting the car.Their eyes were closed, but Katsuki signed his love for the tiny babies all the same, lip quivering as he watched them sleep. /Perfect./
Sleeping peacefully for the moment, nestled into their car seats with the special preemie inserts, were the sweetest little twin boys Eijirou had ever laid eyes on.

And six hours later, car loaded with more paperwork than Shizuko was likely to generate in the entirety of the first grade, a giant cooler full of donor milk, and the most precious cargo of all, Eijirou was even more sure.

“Yeah. We do.”

“Hah.” Eijirou wrapped an arm around Katsuki’s waist. “Well, I have enough practice being nervous for the both of us. We’re going be okay. This stuff isn’t easy… but look at everything we’ve already done together. We got this.”
“You know something?” Katsuki asked.“What’s that?”“I’ve never been nervous for a damn thing in my life until today.”

“It’s a lot sooner than I was expecting,” Eijirou admitted, running his thumb along the travel mug lid. “But I think it’s going to be great.”
“Incredible,” Katsuki agreed, a rare misty look crossing his face.
“Can you believe this is the /second/ most life-changing thing we’re going to do today?” Eijirou pondered aloud as Shizuko ran through the elementary school doors for her first day of first grade.
/ONE YEAR LATER/

“You bet, sweetheart. Come here. Let’s celebrate with strawberries.”

🌥💥⛅️💥🌤💥☀️
“Hey Daddy, can I—Daddy?”Eijirou turned around to see Shizuko standing behind him with a box of strawberries.

He felt complete.
“I promise!”Eijirou melted into Katsuki’s arms, feeling weight lift from his chest at the comforting weight of the metal around his finger.
Katsuki steadied Eijirou’s hands, pulled the ring from the box, and slid it onto Eijirou’s finger. “Promise to talk to me with those hands and that ring every day for the rest of our lives.”

“Y-yes, of course, yes! Katsuki, I’m so happy!”
Eijirou wanted to take in every detail of the intricate – but definitely /manly/ carvings along the surface of the ruby-encrusted ring, but he could hardly see it through the happy tears in his eyes.
“Well?” Katsuki asked, dropping to one knee in front of Eijirou. “I hear you and your daughter liked the sound of ‘Forever’.”
RT @NotZombrigit: AAAAAAA HE DID!!!!!!🥰🥰🥰🥰
Eijirou opened it, and—oh./Oh./
Eijirou lifted the box out of the bubble wrap, then startled when a second box fell into his lap. “What’s this?”“Go on.”
“Huh?”“Open the rest of it.”
RT @NotZombrigit: Did he do what I think he did
RT @NotZombrigit: https://t.co/FAdKzhQjSX
“Back where it belongs,” said Katsuki. “Take a good look in that bubble wrap.”
“Never thought I’d see this again,” he sighed fondly, gently peeling the bubble wrap from the box of the black cape variant All Might and Crimson Riot team-up set he’d once sold Katsuki.
Eijirou smiled when he came across a familiar box.

The last stack of boxes to unpack housed Katsuki’s hero collectibles, and a serious conversation with Shizuko about them not being toys, the two adults set to work carefully unwrapping them from the cushioning they’d been packed in.
Most of Katsuki’s – like his kitchen tools, for instance – were of superior quality, and Eijirou readily agreed to move his to the attic.
He shoed his new housemates out of the way as he unpacked and settled in with remarkable efficiency, pausing only when they had duplicates of shared items to decide on.

Thirty days be darned, Katsuki paid his last month’s rent in advance and moved his belongings to Eijirou’s – no, /their/ house the next weekend. Any time Eijirou had moved in the past, it had been a chaotic affair, but Katsuki seemed to have it down to a science.
Eijirou grinned. “I like the sound of that.”“Yeah,” Katsuki agreed, pulling Shizuko close and breathing her hair. “I’d like that too.”
In her excitement, Shizuko knocked over Eijirou’s hot chocolate, springing around the edge of the table to jump into Katsuki’s lap. “Really? You’re staying? Forever?”
“Katsuki’s going to move in with us. He’s going to be part of the family now.”
Shizuko’s eyes went wide, looking back and forth between the two of them like it was too good to be true. Eijirou looked to Katsuki, they shared a nod, and he took Shizuko’s hands.
“Yeah.”“Would you like it if that was every day?”
“Can we go out for ice cream after my first day of kindergarten?” she asked, wiggling in her seat.“Better than that,” said Katsuki. “You know how you always like the nights when I stay over?”
Warmed up with hot cocoa at a nearby café, Eijirou started first.“Hey Shizuko. Katsuki and I have something exciting to tell you.”
Katsuki smiled and held both Eijirou’s hands. “Let’s tell her together.”
Eijirou leaned in for a long kiss, chilly autumn air only making his cheeks warmer as he breathed in the joy of their new beginning. “You want to tell Shizuko or should I?”
Eijirou nearly slid into the river as he tackle-hugged Katsuki. “We’re really doing this?”“We’re really doing this.”
“I already gave my landlord thirty days’ notice.”
Katsuki stopped, glanced at Shizuko for a moment, then looked back at Eijirou. “Yeah.”“And?” Eijirou’s heart rate picked up.
“Beginning of needing to bundle up,” Katsuki added, zipping up his jacket so the collar covered his nose.“Or snuggle up,” said Eijirou. “Have you thought anymore about… you know… that thing?”

🌥💥⛅️💥🌤💥☀️

“I know autumn feels like the ending of summer, but it’s always felt like a new beginning to me,” Eijirou mused, arm-in-arm with Katsuki as they walked along the river bank, watching Shizuko collect rocks as they meandered.

/Home,/ Katsuki had said.
 /Yes… it /should/ be just one home for us all…/

🌥💥⛅️💥🌤💥☀️
Shizuko got a head start filling them in on their way to the car, and Eijirou basked in the sunshine of it.
“Sounds like you had a great first day,” said Katsuki, ruffling her hair. “How about we go celebrate and get something to eat before we go home, and you can tell us all about it?”

They all fawned over Miko for a few minutes, and Eijirou and Katsuki introduced themselves to Beni’s parents. Finally Shizuko handed the baby back to her mother, holding up her head with the tenderest care, and gave Eijirou a hug.
“I see you made another friend,” said Eijirou, nodding towards the newborn.“Dis is Miko, Beni’s little sister!” said Shizuko. “She’s so little!”
The baby squirmed and cooed, and Shizuko smiled with delight, marveling at the tiny fingers wrapped around her thumb.

Beni was standing with two people Eijirou guessed were his parents, watching closely as Shizuko sat in the little kiddie-sized rocking chair, holding a newborn baby with a look of absolute awe in her eyes.
RT @NotZombrigit: just soul mate things
Katsuki came along, eager to congratulate her on her first day, and when they walked through the classroom door, Eijirou’s heart melted into a puddle at what he saw.
The morning passed easily and full of laughter at the arcade, and before Eijirou knew it, it was time to pick up Shizuko.
Katsuki grinned. “What else did you think the 1 meant?”“Ah, yeah, that adds up.”“Wanna fight me for it now?”“Oh, you’re /on/,” Eijirou agreed.
“YOU were KB1?” Eijirou asked in awe as Katsuki punched his initials into a scoreboard. “I spent half of sophomore year trying to knock you off the number one spot.”
Most of the surrounding shops and restaurants had changed over time, but the arcade looked just like he remembered it.
Fifteen minutes later, they were parked at a strip mall Eijirou vaguely recognized, then realized with delight was a place he’d spent countless hours as a teenager.
Despite it being Eijirou’s car, Katsuki got in the driver’s seat. With how much his hands were shaking, Eijirou thought this was just as well.

“Ask me again when I can see straight,” said Eijirou. “I can hardly believe it’s real.”Katsuki hummed and jerked his head towards the car. “Come on. I took the day off. Let’s go act like /we’re/ kids for the day.”
“Amazing,” said Eijirou. “She made a new friend already. I’m so proud of her.”“You should be,” said Katsuki, handing Eijirou one of the coffee cups. “And you? How do you feel?”
“Figured you might want some of that ‘moral support’ shit you’re always going on about,” said Katsuki, nodding to two coffee cups on the roof before folding Eijirou into a hug. “How’s she doing?”
He was so caught up in the emotion of the moment that he didn’t notice the hot blond in front of his car door until he tried to reach through him with his keys. “Ah! Katsuki! Hi!”

He rejoined his daughter and her new friend, then told her he was on his way out, and Shizuko promised she remembered everything they’d talked about and she’d be okay. Trembling, Eijirou kissed her forehead, signed /I love you,/ and left the classroom.
“She’ll be fine, Mr. Kirishima. Look at her. She’s already doing great.”“Yeah,” Eijirou agreed. “That’s my girl. Well… okay. See you at 1:30 then.”
“You can go,” said Tsu. “Class gets out at 1:30.”Eijirou’s heart skipped a beat. “You sure I shouldn’t stay and keep an eye on her a while?”
Eijirou beamed with pride as the kids got better acquainted with each other and their devices, then checked with Tsu.“So uh… what do I do now?”

“Oh,” said Beni. “I’m glad they work. You’re fun to talk to. Wanna see my insulin pump?” He pulled up his shirt and showed her a patch on his belly with tubing that led to a device clipped to his waistband. “This makes it so I don’t need so many needles.”
Eijirou swallowed, curious how she’d respond, but he needn’t have worried.“Hearing aids,” she said simply with a placid shrug. “I’m almost deaf without them.”

With her head tipped up to peek at the block, her hair all slid back and Beni cocked his head, noticed her hearing aids for the first time.

“What’s /that/?” he asked, pointing at them.

Within minutes, the two had constructed a block tower that reached as high as their little hands could reach. Shizuko was just a tiny bit taller, and she stretched to put on one more block as Beni watched in awe.
“Okay! What else do you like to do?”Beni grabbed Shizuko’s arm and pulled her towards a row of toy trucks full of blocks. “Wanna build a tower?”
“You’re good at this!” said the kid once Shizuko was upright again. “What’s your name?”“Shizuko. What’s yours?”“I’m Beni! Wanna be friends?”
It took Shizuko a couple tries, but by attempt number three, she’d kicked up to a handstand just like her new friend. Eijirou was glad they’d opted for the pair of short under her sundress.
“Sure,” said the kid, kicking off the wall and hopping up on his feet again. “It’s easy! You just put your hands on the floor like this, jump up, and—ta-da! Handstand!”
Shizuko walked right up to a boy who was doing a handstand up against the wall and had his t-shirt hanging over his face.“Dat looks fun,” she said. “Can you show me how?”
“It’s free play for the first half hour while the rest of the kids arrive. Try out some the toys, or the rice table over there, or if you’re feeling brave, make some new friends.”
“Call me Tsu,” the teacher insisted. “You have everything you need now, yes?”Shizuko nodded. “Got it! What next?”

In her classroom, the teacher Ms. Tsuyu showed Shizuko to her cubby and tested the microphone setup, and when Shizuko confirmed that the transmission to her hearing aids was working, she bowed and said proudly, “Tank you Miss Tsuyu.”
“I’m ready, Daddy,” she promised at the door.“Hell yeah you are,” Eijirou said, trying to keep his voice steady.
The whole drive to the preschool, Eijirou drilled her on all the procedures they’d discussed, and by the time they arrived, Shizuko was chiding him for worrying too much.
He hardly slept, but in the morning his nerves were kept far at bay by Shizuko’s excitement, and they made it out the door in record time.
When he kissed her goodnight that evening, Eijirou too was finally as excited as she was. They were really doing this. It was really happening.

For Eijirou to be able to think through even a little obstacle like making cue cards understandable for multiple ages, and for Shizuko to have an active had in the solution itself, was a proud moment a long time coming.

The solution was a small win, but it didn’t feel small. So many other four-year-olds and their parents would be taking a night like this for granted, but for Eijirou and Shizuko, he road to this moment had been long, lined with potholes and detours and missing road signs.
Shizuko chose pictures and symbols she’d remember herself so she could recognize each card, and Eijirou watched with pride as she colored a little microphone with a red X over it.

Eijirou called her into the kitchen and explained his plan, then spread out the /old/ box of crayons – after gently reminding her that the tempting brand new one in her backpack was to be saved for school the next day – and set about explaining each card.
He looked up at the fridge, and inspiration struck. Of course! Pictures! Shizuko /loved/ coloring, and the index cards were blank on the back. Perfect.
/Okay. You’ve come this far,/ he told himself. /You can figure this out./
Stressed, he tried calling Katsuki, but it went to voicemail. He hadn’t really expected Katsuki to pick up, since he was stuck working late on a team project at work, but still…
@priscaofhobiton MY HEART thank you so much! ❤️‍🔥
/Great,/ he chided himself, adrenaline spiking. /What use is a card for every scenario if she doesn’t know which one to use?/
But, as Eijirou flipped through the stack of cards and tried to think if there were any more he should add, he realized one obvious problem: Shizuko couldn’t read yet.
Eijirou had even written up a set of back-up index cards that she could give to her teacher or another adult in the event of technical difficulties like “the microphone isn’t working”.

Ms. Tsuyu had readily agreed to wear a microphone, and they’d tested the setup with the help of the audiologist weeks ahead of time. An extra charger for Shizuko’s hearing aids had been purchased and would be available in the office if needed.

Eijirou knew he had no reason to be nervous. Shizuko was over the moon to be finally starting preschool, and they’d met with the teacher as well as the program director ahead of time to plan ahead for accommodations.
Of this Eijirou had no doubt, but he dutifully reminded her not to rub this fact in the faces of other children.

Fifteen hours to go. Shizuko was as excited as Christmas Eve, speculating about what activities they might try first, and boasting that she was going to be better at the monkey bars than every other kid in class.

Cheese cubes, spicy noodles, and strawberries were prepped and waiting in the respective compartments of the kitty-shaped tupperware with the matching ice pack. Shizuko had picked out a new sundress with sharks jumping over Saturn against a background of bright orange.

🌥💥⛅️💥🌤💥☀️

The crayons were packed. Everything on the Suns & Stars Preschool supply checklist had been accounted for.

When they reached Eijirou’s house, she was uncharacteristically patient and pliant long enough for him to get her out of her car seat, but as soon as they were through the door, she beelined for her room and slammed the door.
The drive was eerily quiet and still, and Shizuko said nothing when they parked at Katsuki’s apartment building and he went inside for ingredients, nor anything when they were underway again.

Eijirou almost forgot they were supposed to stop at Katsuki’s apartment for food, and had to double back when a restaurant sign advertising a soup and salad special reminded him that Katsuki had promised to cook. “You still making soup?” he asked.“Yeah.”

What if she had?

She’ll never know. Distance is cruel, and time is merciless.

This time, the ocean only keeps her awake as she stares past the horizon and grieves for what never was.
Momo could have just made them some heavy duty earplugs, but the ocean sounds seemed so romantic. Not that she said anything about it that.

She’s not. Momo’s lying on her back in a room overlooking the ocean, remembering the time she and Jirou shared a cheap hotel on a work study and it was too noisy to sleep, so Jirou plugged her jacks into the wall and amplified the nearby ocean sounds to lull them to sleep.
Hell, for all she knows, Momo could be on her second child too…

Once upon a time, she would have called Momo at a time like this and poured her heart out to her. But now the thought makes her squirm. It’d be like trauma dumping on a stranger. She doesn’t even KNOW this girl anymore.

She’s SO fucking lonely. All her old high school friends are in other cities, some of them are married (Ochako’s already pregnant with her SECOND), some are working abroad. Some she has no idea. Like Momo. Is she still in Hokkaido? It’s sad that she doesn’t know.

It’s probably just her imagination, but she could swear she smells the campfire. And Momo. God, she hasn’t smelled her in so long. She wonders what she’s up to. If she still cares. Why she hasn’t texted in so long. But it’s her fault too, she hasn’t reached out either.

She throws the dress in the garbage (what a waste of ¥10,000) and sits in bed in — oh. It’s Momo’s old UA hoodie, the one she lent her on a camping trip after she fell in the creek and was shivering by the campfire.
Too tired to feign excitement, and nervous that her stupid dress is going to make her roommate sick - for fuck’s sake, the last thing she wants is to get puked on too - Jirou calls it an early night.

As if THAT wasn’t enough, she comes home to an announcement that her roommate is pregnant. She tries to be happy for her - even though her roommate is trying not to gag at the smell of spilled wine on Jirou’s dress - but she’s so lonely, and the roommate is moving out.

Meanwhile, in Kyoto, Jirou is having a horrible day. She went to *another* friend’s wedding, just to get red wine spilled on her by the best man at the reception, and then got pulled over and ticketed for a DUI when all she’d nursed at the wedding was a bottomless iced tea.

But it’s been so long since they’ve shared so much as a text message, it feels weird to even try now. What would she say? 

How’s the weather in Kyoto? Been on any cool missions lately? 

It all sounds so shallow and empty, so she doesn’t send anything at all.

But five years after graduating, Momo wakes up from an erotic dream about Jirou and can’t shake the thought from her head. It’s WEIRD to think about now. She’s sad they drifted apart. Wonders what could have been. Wishes they didn’t live so far away.

Pretty soon they started forgetting to wish each other happy birthday, or to ask how their parents were doing, and before they knew it, they just… weren’t friends anymore. Nothing happened, really. Neither could say when it stopped.
But their jobs were in different cities, and they were busy as hell as rookies. They had roommates to talk to at the end of the day, and as time went on they talked less and less.

They made it through the war. Graduated. Got their full licenses. 

And for a while they talked, texted each other in between shifts to talk about their days or new goings on in their lives.

Countless times she ALMOST said something when they got a little too close, but every time she lost their nerve. It wasn’t worth it, right? Momo was probably straight. She’s probably be grossed out or feels objectified if Jirou admitted her feelings for her.

But Momo was always so prim and proper, came from a wealthy family… she was a little intimidating. And so gorgeous, built like a goddess.  Even on the shot-in-the-dark off chance that she was interested in girls, surely she would never think of humble Jirou that way.

Meanwhile Jirou went to sleep every night imagining what it’d be like to be the little spoon curled up against Momo’s curves, dreaming that maybe someday those moments of laughing together would turn into kissing.

Sure, GOOD friends. Friends who’d been through hell and back together and seen some serious shit. But you know. Just friends.

Besides, Jirou seemed to have a thing for Kaminari, right? And Momo didn’t have much of anything in common with Kaminari…

All throughout school, through the war, through everything, Momo was interested in Jirou, curious about her, wanting to read her like she’d read so many books.

But they were just friends, right?

The night had been long, the winter cold and dark, but the explosion of Katsuki’s kiss was first warm sunrise of spring.

🌥💥⛅️💥🌤💥☀️
A residual ache deep in his heart, one that had been there so long he hardly noticed it anymore, began to dissolve as their chests pressed against each other and made one another warm.

“You heard the girl,” said Katsuki, taking Eijirou’s other hand and pulling himself up.

“Loud and clear,” Eijirou breathed, surrendering to the gravity that pulled him closer to Katsuki’s body.
“Yeah. Like you just saw. Kissing and stuff. You okay with me kissing your dad?”Shizuko nodded. “He not look that happy in long time. You betta kiss him again.”
Eijirou had to bite down on the loose straps of his apron to hold back a sob.Shizuko tilted her head at Katsuki. “More dan fwiends?”

“We’ll see,” he said. “This is all new. I don’t live here—” he cast his eyes back up at Eijirou for a second “—yet. But your dad’s pretty special. And so are you. I think I’d like to get to know him as more than friends, if that’s alright with you.”
Katsuki smiled, and with one hand around Eijirou’s for balance, knelt down carefully to eye level with her without hurting his ankle.
“You stay, teacher?” she asked, looking up at him with eyes shining with hope.

He loosened his grip only when Katsuki started laughing, and he looked down to see why – Shizuko had wrapped her arms around Katsuki’s good leg, nuzzling her forehead against the seams of his jeans and making it a bona fide group hug.
/I’m home,/ Eijirou thought, wrapping his arms around Katsuki’s back with the intent to never let go, tears of joy tickling his eyelashes.

Like the sun bursting through the clouds after a gust of tropical wind, comforting heat such as Eijirou had never known washed over his body as he lost all sense of time in the embrace of Katsuki’s lips and the beat of his heart against his own.

Katsuki took Eijirou by the shoulders and looked straight into his eyes, lighting a fire with no need for a match, pushed him up against the coat closet door, and kissed him like their lives depended on it.
Feeling like he was fifteen and unaccustomed to his own limbs, his voice cracked as he tripped over his own tongue, babbling all at once, “Willyougooutwithme?”
Katsuki raised an eyebrow. “Go on.”
“Katsuki,” he blurted out as Shizuko was taking the bags of clothes to her room. “I need to ask you something. Right now.”
RT @NotZombrigit: head empty only bakugo, I can relate

He had no speech rehearsed, no romantic music or mood lighting, and not even a thread of a safety net if this went badly, but his body had taken the lead and there was no turning back. It had to be done.
Shizuko looked just as baffled while the three of them made their way toward the house, and truth be told, Eijirou didn’t have a plan. He hadn’t thought this through even a little bit.
“Oi, hair for brains, didn’t you forget something?” Katsuki asked when they parked. “Uh… no,” said Eijirou, heart racing. “Come inside.”“Okay…”
Eijirou knew the way to Katsuki’s apartment without help by that point, but he didn’t go there. Unbidden, his hands and feet took him back to his own house.

Manga: My Hero Academia [Vol.7 Extra] https://t.co/76RphduP4X
someone who took the time to explain an emergency room visit to her when /he/ was the one with a broken bone, someone whose phone lock screen was still a crayon picture Shizuko had drawn…

But it seemed him might not have to, for here was someone in the passenger seat of his car, unbothered by the clever arrangement of mirrors that allowed him to reinforce his conversation with Shizuko with sign language,
Honestly, Eijirou hadn’t given much thought to how being a single parent would impact his dating life. He’d hardly thought about his dating life at all.

Katsuki and Shizuko settled into easy conversation as they pulled out of the parking lot, and Eijirou couldn’t stop smiling. This was so right. So comfortable. Katsuki was the whole damn package – smart, attractive, took absolutely no shit, and /talked to his kid./
“Completely,” Katsuki chuckled, pulling the apron off the seat and tying it around his waist.Damn, he had a nice figure.
“Eijirou, what the heck is this?” he asked in between guffaws.“A little present,” said Eijirou, flashing his teeth as he showed off his own. “Accurate, don’t you think?”
It was worth the wait. Katsuki hobbled out of the lab with a serious case of resting bitch face, but when he opened the door, he burst out laughing.

At 3:01, Eijirou pulled up at the curb outside Katsuki’s lab, trying not to laugh as he made sure the print on the apron was visible. He’d hung the other one over the passenger seat and was eagerly awaiting Katsuki’s reaction.

“You like this one?” he asked her.“Yeah! Oddah ones bowwing,” Shizuko explained. Eijirou imagined her showing it off to kindergarten classmates, and his eyes got a little misty. Maybe. Maybe. He made a mental note to bring it up again at their next session with Mic.
He draped the aprons over his arm just as Shizuko brought him a bright purple backpack with UFOs and planets, complete with star-shaped zipper pulls.

Somehow, though, he found himself leafing through a rack of aprons at another store while Shizuko picked out a backpack. Side by side, he found aprons that read “Get the F*** out of my kitchen” and “I’m just hungry”, and couldn’t resist.
While she was trying on red sneakers, he thought with a chuckle about buying a pair of high heels just to make Katsuki laugh, but he didn’t think he’d be able to stand in them, much less vacuum.

Back at home, he set Shizuko up with a coloring book and hurried through his list of work tasks. The early start made for an early finish, and after a light lunch he took them shopping for some new clothes since Shizuko had been growing like a dandelion in the sun.
But it wasn’t just about his child. She’d brought them together, yes, but… Eijirou was certain he’d be enjoying these carpools just as much as a bachelor.

He /got/ her, and Eijirou could see in her eyes that she’d been waiting half her life for someone to understand.

Shizuko /needed/ Katsuki in her life, if Eijirou was being honest with himself. And that meant Eijirou needed him too.

Katsuki had told Eijirou he’d never be good with kids, but nothing could be farther from the truth. Shizuko got on well with Daisuke, her speech therapist Mic, and most other people they encountered, but no one made her smile quite like Katsuki did.

Katsuki’s batteries were almost done for after their bizarre night, but Shizuko was more than happy to ask him with her hands if he wanted to try her favorite cereal with the strawberry flavored marshmallows.

It felt like family.
Shizuko had been elated at the extra company, telling Katsuki in elaborate detail about her dreams in sign over breakfast, before either of them had their hearing aids in.
Katsuki had taken the liberty of making them coffee, and somehow with the same machine and ingredients, it tasted better when he made it.

When he’d opened his eyes at noon after inviting Katsuki into his bed, warm and comforted by the shared space and the soft sound of his breathing, any echo of doubt in Eijirou’s mind was silenced. He wanted to wake up like that every morning and fall asleep like that every night.
but Eijirou was enjoying both the domestic feeling of the errands, and the excuse to spend more time with Katsuki.
It was a temporary arrangement, this shuttle service for his friend with the broken ankle – one Katsuki had agreed to only under duress after a great deal of insisting he could still drive –

Katsuki didn’t answer, but quickly signed something to Shizuko through the car window that made her giggle. Wondering what sort of mischief those two were planning, Eijirou grinned as he turned around and drove away from the chemistry lab.
“Lazy ass,” said Katsuki, but the bite was gone from his voice, the sharp edges at his eyes and lips had softened. “I’m off at three. Don’t be late.”“Shall I come in heels?” Eijirou teased.
Eijirou barely suppressed a snort. “Bold of you to assume I vacuum at all, let alone in heels. And /you’re welcome,/ ya big sourpuss. I’m normally still asleep at this hour, you know.”
Katsuki turned around and gave him the stink eye. “If you’re waiting for me to congratulate you for vacuuming in heels or something, it’s not going to happen.”

🌥💥⛅️💥🌤💥☀️

“Have a good day at work!” Eijirou waved cheerily as Katsuki stepped out of his car.

“That’s probably a good idea,” says Melissa. “Just to be sure. Yeah.”

So they take a step forward, and their lips meet again. It’s just as good the next morning; better, even, knowing it’s the real thing.

And maybe they’re a little late for work that day.

“I um. I kinda liked it.”

“Yeah,” says Melissa, her hands brushing her lips. “I did too.”

“But I mean… we should probably try it again when we’re sober,” says Deirdre, fiddling with the hem of her shirt. “Right? Just to make sure?”

The next morning, they’re not sure what comes next. They meet again in the hall, a little shy, a little hungover. 

“So… about last night…” says Deirdre

“Yeah,” says Melissa. “I guess we should probably talk about that.”
But soon it’s intentional, hungry, passionate.

The roommate is sure taking their sweet time, and pretty soon the bottle is empty. They’re still talking, and they’re just. So. Close. 

And then they’re more than close, they’re kissing. They hardly even realize they’re doing it at first, that’s how right it feels.

(cw alcohol) 

Melissa grabs a bottle of Moscato and sits with Deirdre in the hall passing the bottle back and forth until her roommate gets home with the other key. They talk about their respective rough days, cry a little, laugh a little. Blush a lot.
Then one day Melissa comes back from her family’s place after saying goodbye to a pet, and Deirdre is just getting back from bad news at a doctor appointment, and she’s locked out.

Five years of cuddling on the couch for movie nights, or binge watching three straight seasons of whatever Deirdre’s hyperfixated on this month. Five years of running across the hall in a towel to borrow a pad when shark week got here before pay day.

Okay hear me out. Imagine: it’s been five seasons since Deirdre moved into the apartment across the hall from Melissa. Five years of them being each other’s shoulders to cry on after breakups and lost jobs.
I swear I do think 90% of the times I pick up my phone or walk into another room 😅

Eijirou could get used to this.

🌥💥⛅️💥🌤💥☀️
It took the blond a while to stop shivering, and Eijirou even dared to wrap an arm around him, surprised when instead of tensing or throwing him off, Katsuki’s muscles softened at his touch.
Katsuki belonged there next to him. Eijirou was certain of it.
RT @NotZombrigit: https://t.co/lgaOsb6aLE
Seeing Katsuki settling into his bed cemented his decision, and instead of feeling that he was taking something away, it felt like he was filling an empty space that had changed form to fit him.
He’d hung up his rings. Decided to move on. Acknowledged to himself that he was in love.

He’d thought it would feel all wrong, seeing someone else there. But as Katsuki climbed into bed, Eijirou felt something inside him shift. He’d been thinking of it as /Haruka’s side of the bed/ all this time, but that time was over.
It took him a minute with his injured ankle, but it gave Eijirou a moment to slow down and process the moment.

Eijirou took Katsuki’s arm, and trembling with nerves to match Katsuki’s shivers, walked them back to his bedroom. The pillow was still in the living room, so he told Katsuki to wait a moment and ran back for it, then set it on the bed and gestured for Katsuki to get in.
@NotZombrigit Wouldn’t be manly to let your bro shiver when he’s cold and traumatized and has a broken ankle.
RT @NotZombrigit: cuddles are absolutely required
/Yes./

Eijirou swallowed, heart suddenly pounding. Katsuki was visibly shivering. He really was cold, and that was no good. He should be as comfortable as possible while he recovered from his injury and otherwise rough night.
RT @NotZombrigit: https://t.co/L5Eg1fgyQO
/Unless…//Are we going or not??/

Eijirou couldn’t deny that sharing the bed with a warm body sounded wonderful. After such a stressful and upsetting several hours, nothing sounded better than being right next to the person he’d just feared losing.
Or would it?
/Well…/ Eijirou grimaced.That’d be crazy, right? This night had thrown enough at them, surely complicating whatever they were by /sleeping together/ would be a terrible idea.
/So tired,/ Eijirou backpedaled. /I wasn’t thinking…/Katsuki actually laughed. /So you /didn’t/ just invite me into your bed?/
Katsuki blinked. /What??/Eijirou froze, realizing what he’d just suggested. “Uh…” he stammered aloud, brain too sleepy to think of a way out of his inappropriate suggestion.
@NotZombrigit Hehehe
RT @NotZombrigit: BACK TO BED YOU SAY
That made sense. He’d only given Katsuki a t-shirt, and the living room throw blankets were pretty thin./Sorry,/ he said, yawning. /It’s cold out here. Come back to bed./

Eijirou walked up next to him and tapped his arm, motioning towards the water. /Why?/ he signed. /Are you okay? In pain?/Katsuki looked startled, but he shut off the water and shook his head. /Cold./
@purpleinsomnia1 SAME. HERE. i swear I have days like this all the time.
RT @purpleinsomnia1: This sounds SO MUCH like something that would happen to me, it's almost painful 😆
Frowning, Eijirou slid out of bed and walked out to the kitchen, where he found Katsuki bracing himself over the sink with the hot water running. Weird.

Eijirou hadn’t realized that he had fallen asleep at all until he woke up. He sat up, rubbing his eyes and trying to figure out what had woken him. There was no sound coming Shizuko’s room, and he was a comfortable temperature, but he had an anxious feeling nonetheless.
@vibrant_leaf It’s underway!!

Perhaps Shizuko could have a little loft over the crib, and they could probably find room for a changing table in the living room if he rearranged his office furniture a bit, or maybe he could just line up his filing cabinets and lay a changing pad on top of those…
Eijirou drifted into an uneasy sleep, imagining how he’d divvy up the house for a new child.

/“Whoever said you can’t miss what you never had was full of shit.”/ Eijirou remembered Katsuki saying a while back, and he had never agreed more. He missed the very idea of his second child, just as much as Katsuki missed the very idea of his first.
@purpleinsomnia1 It’s in progress!! 😊
He’d been so overwhelmed with raising just one child, he hadn’t given so much as a passing thought to raising two, but it had been something he and Haruka had talked about.
It had been a long time since he’d even thought about their tentative plans to have another child, but being back in that hospital put it right at the forefront of his mind and made him ache.
His mind wandered back to a simpler time before all this, a time before the scars and the speech therapy and herculean task of single parenting.
All the same, it had been a hell of a night, and as tired as he was, Eijirou couldn’t sleep.
At least Katsuki wasn’t angry about the lockout. He’d worried for a moment that the night was about to take a terribly awkward unpleasant turn, and he was relieved at having been spared /that/ fate.

He hadn’t thought it would make that much difference, but it was strange being in bed without the other pillow. He felt both too empty and too full at the same time, lonely but tangled in too many thoughts, tired and grieving and amused and hopeful all at once.

Katsuki shrugged. “Whatever. Building manager’s got a master key. I’ll call her in the morning.”“Okay. Goodnight.” Eijirou gave him a little wave, then shuffled down the hall to his room and changed back into pajamas of his own.
“Sure.” Eijirou took the one from his desk and plugged it in near the couch. “Well uh… get some good rest, I guess. Sorry for locking you out of your apartment.”
“Um… nothing. It’s just been a long night. Do you need anything else?”“Got an extra phone charger?
“What’s wrong?” Katsuki asked as he took the pillow, looking sideways at Eijirou’s pained expression.

Eijirou brought him sweats and a t-shirt, then gathered up the throw blankets from around the living room, and finally – with a bit of trepidation – went back to his room to bring him the pillow that had once belonged to Haruka.
“Yeah,” said Katsuki, frowning at the scuffs on his clothes. “These are a mess from the fall.”

“We don’t exactly have a posh guest room or anything, but that couch is pretty comfy,” said Eijirou once they made it. “I’ve crashed there many times when I was too tired to drag my butt to bed. And I can lend you some clean pajamas if you want.”

Shizuko was still fast asleep, so they took the drive in silence, but it was a comfortable one this time. Back home, Eijirou carried Shizuko in first, tucked her into bed, and went back to help Katsuki inside.
Getting down the stairs in the walking cast was considerably harder than walking up, but they managed to get back to the car without incident.
“Well. Only one thing to do,” said Eijirou. “You’re coming with me.”Katsuki almost started laughing again. “What else?”“Exactly. Let’s go.”
“Winner, winner,” said Katsuki, shaking his head again.
“Let me guess,” said Eijirou, scratching the back of his neck. “You didn’t exactly grab your keys on the way out the door mid-panic attack?”

“Oh, this is /just perfect/,” Katsuki shook his head when the laughter had subsided. “Of course. Of course the fucking door is locked. It’s three o’clock in the morning, I’m freezing my ass off, my ankle is broken, and the fucking. Door. Is locked.”

🌥💥⛅️💥🌤💥☀️

For a second, Eijirou froze, horrified that Katsuki was crying. But then, a confused and dopey grin split his face when he realized he was actually /laughing./

“Idiot. You locked the door, didn’t you?”

🌥💥⛅️💥🌤💥☀️
Eijirou nodded, watching while Katsuki reached into his pocket, then grimaced before trying the door with gritted teeth.
“Yeah. We’re good,” said Katsuki. “Thanks for… taking care of me, or whatever. Tell Shizuko in the morning too.”
“Hmm?” Katsuki put his hands on Eijirou’s shoulders, pulling him up so they were facing each other again.“I asked if we’re okay,” Eijirou said again, heart pounding as he waited for the answer.

Eijirou threw his arms around Katsuki, trembling though he was the one with two sturdy feet, overcome with both exhaustion and relief. 

“Are we okay?” he mumbled into Katsuki’s shoulder, resisting the temptation to dissolve into tears for yet another time that night.
And the glare was gone.“Yeah. Okay.”

“Loss,” said Eijirou. “I… I was so scared on the way over, I didn’t know what happened to you, I feared the worst, and—I’m just so glad you’re okay, and—maybe this isn’t what I was going for back there, but I—can I please hug you?”
“I—oh. I guess I should have figured that. You did seem, I don’t know, pretty lucid with Shizuko and everything. I don’t know. Maybe I just got scared.”Katsuki’s glare softened. “Scared of what?”
“I only let them give me ibuprofen,” said Katsuki. “I’m under no influence.”

“I didn’t… I didn’t think the time was right,” said Eijirou. “I mean… we’re all tired, you’ve had a bunch of pain medication… I didn’t want to take advantage of you, that wouldn’t be manly at all, and—”
Eijirou tried to stare at his shoes, but Katsuki pushed his chin up.“Explain,” he tried again.
Katsuki stood in front of his door, arms crossed, staring him down. “The hell did you want to tell me? And why didn’t you kiss me?”
Shizuko was sound asleep once they arrived, so he parked at the curb with his hazard lights on so he could see the car from Katsuki’s door, then helped walk him up the stairs.
The drive back to Katsuki’s apartment was even more cold in its silence than the one on the way to the hospital, and this time Eijirou’s gut was filled with a whole new dread.
The look of hurt in Katsuki’s eyes at those words sent a thousand daggers through his already raw heart.
“I don’t think we should do this right now,” said Eijirou, harnessing all his willpower to turn his face away. “Let’s just get you home for now.”
But Katsuki’s hands were on his face, wiping away the water that had taken the place of his tears, and Eijirou gasped. They were so close – he was so warm – he could just—
“Were you crying?”Eijirou bit his lip. “Yeah. It’s uh… it’s a lot. I’ll tell you more later, but I wanted to talk to you about—”
They were just waiting on paperwork to take home, and Eijirou was ready to change his mind and wait for a better time, but Katsuki gave him a pointed look an motioned for him to sit.
He’d escaped with a minor fracture, fortunately, and though he’d need to return for re-evaluation later that week, he was free to go home.
In the brief time he’d been gone, Katsuki had been fitted with the walking cast that he’d be wearing for the next few days until the swelling had gone down.
Eijirou splashed some water on his face, looked himself in the eyes in the mirror, and walked back to the treatment room with purpose.

And their search for tools to make her life better had led them to Katsuki.

Perhaps… perhaps even in this tumultuous place, on this frightening and painful night, there was still a chance at a new beginning.

For all the anguish, Eijirou had been blessed with hope. His daughter lived. The explosion that had claimed Haruka’s life had spared his child’s, and though it left her changed, she was a little fighter, a tiny force to be reckoned with.

Oh, what a wonderful older sister Shizuko would have been. Seeing how she comforted Katsuki in his time of need made him certain of it. Imagining her kissing the forehead of a newborn brother who could never be was almost more than Eijirou could bear.And yet…

Another wave of grief crashed over Eijirou’s head for the child who never was, a baby who was never more than a smile and a kiss late at night, their very possibility chased to an early grave with their mother.
He remembered leaving the hospital with Haruka and newborn Shizuko, thinking that he hoped if they were to return, it would be to have another child.

and Eijirou felt so small, like he was holding snapping twigs in the raging wind.

Residual adrenaline from his fear of losing Katsuki, relief that he had only minor injuries, and happy memories of the most joyous day of his life all swirled in the hurricane that was his grief for his late wife;
Eijirou ran down the hall as soon as the door was closed behind him, found the nearest restroom, and stopped with his arms against the inside of a stall door, shaking with silent sobs.
“Do you mind watching her for a minute?” he asked Katsuki. “I gotta use the bathroom.”“Go ‘head,” Katsuki nodded, then returned to his conversation with Shizuko.

Shizuko and Katsuki were deep in conversation, and while it soothed his heart to see them cheering each other up, neither of them had any idea what turmoil Eijirou was trying to breathe through as he spent hours in this surprisingly familiar building.
They were in between doctors, nurses – whoever else they were supposed to meet; Eijirou had lost track.

Eijirou tried at first to stop her, sure it must be irritating while he was trying to listen, but he Katsuki insisted that it wasn’t. He happily interpreted for her, explaining what the doctors were looking for, and how a fracture differed from a complete break.

Whenever the doctors were in action, he had the distraction of paying attention to them, as well as enduring Shizuko’s many questions about what was going on – all directed at Katsuki of course, since she couldn’t hear the doctors.
or to glance down at her soft brown hair and marvel at how it had grown since her birth, or to remember playing with Haruka’s hair when it was /her/ sleeping in his lap long ago.

It was the strangest juxtaposition of emotions, though, for there was a great deal of hurry-up-and-wait. Eijirou had entirely too much time to stare at the curtains and remember doing the same thing was awaiting Shizuko’s grand entrance,

On the contrary, the implicit trust was as warm as the body at his side, and in spite of the unfortunate circumstances, Eijirou felt his budding love for Katsuki unfurling in his chest as it started to see light.
True to form, he refused to let the doctors put him in a wheelchair, preferring instead to walk with Eijirou’s support. This was admittedly much slower, but Eijirou didn’t mind.
Katsuki waved them along to come with him, and they followed along from room to room as he was volleyed from triage to x-rays and more.
Eijirou wasn’t really sure how long they spent in the waiting room, but it must have been a while, because Shizuko was starting to doze off in his lap when they were called back.
He wondered with a sinking heart how many other little things had already been lost in the wind, and he held Shizuko a little tighter.
God, how he missed those little things with Haruka. It was so easy to miss the big things almost constantly, but time had the cruelest way of slowly eroding those little things.
Or how he’d nearly fainted with the OB showed him what seven centimeters looked like.

Things like how Haruka had talked to the colorful fish in between contractions while they waited for a room, or how she had challenged him to squeeze ice chips in his palms as long as he could when he’d been at seven centimeters for three hours and tired and frustrated.

Though technically he was supporting Katsuki’s weight to unburden his injured ankle, he was glad for the strong presence at his side as his head spun with countless minute details about that night he hadn’t thought about in years.
But the waiting room carpets had the same seahorse motif, the layout of fish tanks and chairs was the same, and above all /it smelled the same./
He had thought once they parked nearest the ER, it wouldn’t be so bad. After all, it was a completely different department from labor & delivery, it probably wouldn’t bring back /that/ many memories.

Eijirou’s heart twisted, wishing he could just scoop Katsuki into his arms and kiss the top of his head and tell him it was just a nightmare like he did when Shizuko got scared, but every detail of this was painfully real.

At least Katsuki was an adult with decades of practice in communication in general, but even so, Eijirou was treading water in the deep end, trying to be a lifeguard when he could barely swim.

He could feel the clouds closing in around his heart, dimming his light as he mentally prepared to shut down, to start over, to grieve /again/, to feel all those awful things he’d felt at the beginning, to add another notch to his trauma belt and retreat to damaged loneliness.

What if Katsuki was dying? Or worse, already dead? Eijirou had /just begun/ to feel ready to love again after losing his wife, how brutally unfair would it be to lose Katsuki before ever even really having him?

Eijirou glanced at the little map on his phone far more than was necessary for navigation, both to see if Katsuki had responded, and to give himself something to keep his mind busy and prevent it from spiraling completely.
Deciding the little patch of clear windshield was enough, he put the car in drive and sped off in the direction of Katsuki’s apartment building.
Eijirou swallowed again. He wanted to reassure her, but he didn’t dare lie to her. /I think so,/ he compromised, as much to reassure himself as her.

/What happened to teacher??//All I know is he needs help,/ said Eijirou in between drumming his fingers on the steering wheel impatiently as the little patch of clear glass crept up from the defroster./Is he okay?/

/I don’t know,/ Eijirou admitted before closing the door and taking his own seat. It took agonizingly long for the frost to melt off the windshield while the car warmed up, and his once-sleepy daughter was now on high alert and looking upset.
/Who?/Eijirou swallowed, then told her the truth. /Teacher? What’s wrong? What help?/
/Why now?/ Shizuko asked as Eijirou buckled her into her car seat. /He needs help now,/ he answered once his hands were free.

The text from Izuku had come through, so Eijirou pulled up the address in his maps app, made sure he had his wallet and keys, and yanked a sweatshirt over Shizuko’s head before picking her up and running out the door.
Shizuko slid out of bed and into her shark slippers, and Eijirou grabbed the first pair of shoes in sight and told her to put them on in the car.

/To help a friend,/ he answered, hoping that’d be enough and wouldn’t scare her too much. He was nervous about bringing her into what he desperately hoped /wasn’t/ a dangerous situation, but he didn’t see much choice. /But we need to hurry./

Eijirou hung up and hurried to Shizuko’s room, where he woke her as gently as he could and explained by the glow of the hot air balloon nightlight that they needed to go.Confused, Shizuko rubbed her eyes. /Go? Where? Why?/
“Okay,” said Izuku. “If you’re sure. Text me once you find out what’s going on, okay?”“I will. I gotta go. Send me that address, yeah?”“You got it. Good luck!”

“No, that’s okay, you stay with your family.” He briefly considered asking if he could drop Shizuko off with them, but he didn’t want to waste any more time. She was just going to have to come with him. “I’ll keep you posted if we need any more help, though.”

He seemed like the type to be capable of sending any intruders to the hospital before they could do /him/ any harm, but if it was something else, like if he was trapped under a fallen bookshelf or something, maybe he could use the extra muscle… but then again, the kids…
Eijirou thought about it for a minute, wondering what sort of trouble Katsuki was in.
“Yeah, I’ll text you his address,” said Izuku, his voice shaking. “Do you want me to go with you?”

“Hi Eijirou, what’s up?”“Uh… it’s Katsuki. I think something happened to him. He texted me for help but now he’s not answering my calls and I have no idea what happened. Do you know his address? I think I’d better go see if he’s okay…”
Seeing the map from the aquarium on the counter, he was struck with an idea and unlocked his phone again to call Izuku. He sighed in relief when he answered on the second ring.
Was it even worth trying? Or would checking there only waste precious time?

It seemed extremely unlikely that Katsuki would be at his office so late on a weekend, especially knowing about the uptight building manager who liked to lock down early, but it was the only address he knew.

And yet, Eijirou was out of bed, hopping around the bedroom as he pulled on shoes and threw a coat over his pajamas. After the seventh call went to voicemail, he paced around the kitchen feeling helpless, trying to think what else he could even do.

None of his texts had been read, and as the minutes ticked by, Eijirou began to think he should go check on him instead.

But how? He didn’t even know Katsuki’s address.

🌥💥⛅️💥🌤💥☀️

With the phone on speaker so he could text Katsuki at the same time, Eijirou called over and over, his heart rising higher in his throat each time it went to voicemail.

He reached for his phone to tell Katsuki about it, when suddenly adrenaline burst in his chest. There were two missed calls from him in the last five minutes, and three unread texts.

This was how it should be. Holding his daughter, sharing their love for each other, going on trips with friends to the aquarium, eating ice cream. It had been the perfect day, with the perfect ending.

Eijirou heart melted, and happy tears sprang to his eyes. The breakthrough he’d been waiting for had finally come. /I love you too,/ he told her after wiping his eyes, and scooped her into his arms, shark plush and all.
RT @NotZombrigit: https://t.co/6OFXCV2TXw
Shizuko looked deep into his eyes. /Daddy,/ she signed slowly, though her hands knew the word well, /I love you./
Shizuko was hugging her shark in one arm and looking up at him with the softest expression. Eijirou knelt down in front of her, sensing that she had something important on her mind.

He thought his heart could get no fuller, but the day had one surprise left for him. Later that night, when they had just finished dinner and were looking around for a book Shizuko wanted to bring to her next playdate with Daisuke, Eijirou turned around at a tap on his hand.
Eijirou relayed the message, and Izuku got watery-eyed again.
/Don’t get mushy!/ Katsuki wrote back. Then, a moment later: /Daisuke’s grown a lot since I last saw him. Looks happy too. Tell them all hi for me./
Eijirou knew it was a lot more than that, but he wasn’t sure how to express it over text, so he simply sent back a string of hearts.
/She’s thriving :) / he wrote. /All thanks to you./He didn’t expect an answer any time soon, but one came before he’d locked his phone./Thanks to YOU. I just gave her tools./
Izuku and Ochako hummed their agreement, nuzzling their heads together as they, too, watched the children. Eijirou took a few seconds of video of the kids, then sent it to Katsuki.

“It’s funny,” Eijirou mused, looked at the children as the conversed in sign too quickly for him to keep up. “Your son hears too much, my daughter barely hears at all, and yet they’re perfect for each other.”
Shouto smiled. “I thought he’d like those. Momo will be happy to hear that. She made them.”

“Thanks again for those earmuffs,” said Ochako, beaming at her son as he licked at the ice cream. “I didn’t think an outing like this would ever be possible. He usually gets so overwhelmed in public places like this.”
Shouto bought ice cream for everyone, and they all sat down at a circular table to enjoy the frozen treats and rest their feet.

When they’d traversed the whole building, Shouto led them to the smaller of the two onsite restaurants, one that maintained the dim lights and the calming water tanks, as well as octopus tentacle motifs across the floor.
Soon Shizuko ran ahead to see the sting rays, and the conversation changed as they chased after the children and took in the sights of the many fascinating sea creatures at the local aquarium.
Izuku nodded rapidly, tears dripping onto his collarbones. “Very much.”

Though they were standing indoors in dim lights, surrounded by tanks of marine creatures, Eijirou felt as though the sun were warming his back. “Would it make you happy if I told you I’ve seen him smile?”

“No, it’s not bad at all!” Izuku sniffled. “It’s wonderful! Oh my gosh, does he like you back? I hope he does, he deserves someone like you, he really hasn’t been the same since Esumi left, I would so love to see him happy again…”
To Eijirou’s great surprise, Izuku burst into tears. Panicked, Eijirou looked back and forth between him, Ochako, and Shouto. “Is that bad…?”
“Uhm… yeah, I do,” said Eijirou, surprised by the rush of relief that came with saying it out loud. “Yeah. I like Katsuki. He’s been the best thing in our lives in a long time.”
Izuku was practically vibrating, his eyes aglow as he began to babble. “Katsuki, I’ve called him Kacchan since we were young, but never mind that, you like him? Really?”
This juicy bit of gossip didn’t get past Izuku. “YOU LIKE KACCHAN??” he blurted out.“Ka—what?”
Eijirou felt his ears turning pink as Shizuko giggled, and he caught her unmistakably signing to Daisuke /Daddy likes him!/
Shouto nodded while retying his ponytail. “Yes, I remember. But I’ve learned more about him in the last forty-five minutes than I did that whole afternoon.”
Ochako kept a hand on her son’s shoulder as she chimed in. “You met him once, Shouto, remember? When Daisuke was first learning sign language?”
“A great deal,” Shouto went on. “I feel as though I know him already.”
Eijirou blinked, tearing his eyes away from the octopus tank to meet the two-colored eyes that had seen right through him.“I—do I?”
“You certainly talk about him a lot.”

🤟🏽🤟🏽🤟🏽
Kirishima’s eyes light up, and several questions fly out of his fingers in rapid succession, but the last one stops Bakugou in his mid-breath./Can I kiss you?/
/I was TEACHING Kaminari,/ he explains before he can stop himself. /He’s been bugging me about it for ages. I’m not a damn beginner. And you know a lot more than ‘a bit’, don’t be so humble./
But still, it feels personal, and it doesn’t sit right with him that Kirishima doesn’t know.He can’t take it anymore.
Besides, between hearing aids, sign, and a little lip reading; hell, he can follow a conversation /better/ that some of these hearing extras.

In all fairness, he doesn’t talk about it much if he doesn’t need to. He’s been dealing with it long enough that it’s just background texture in his life, not something that /needs/ to come up in conversation often.
And Bakugou squirms more and more, both at the ongoing façade and at the realization that as close as they’d become, Kirishima really didn’t even know that he was hard of hearing.
But Kirishima has no idea, so he keeps introducing “new” signs, and beaming in approval when Bakugou repeats them correctly on the first try.
But soon it’s absolutely maddening, because damnit he’s lying to Kirishima, and he wants more than anything to drop the act and just /talk to him./
At first, it’s cute how badly Kirishima wants to help. He’s a pretty decent teacher – or at least Bakugou assumes he would be if this was actually new information.
@sascakegia Oh girl. I’ll DM you when I finish posting this thread. It’s. A lot lol.
And that’s how, two days later, Bakugou finds himself sitting on the edge of Kirishima’s bed, pretending to practice signing /You’re so manly/ for the first time.
“Oh, dude, you guys are learning sign language? That’s so cool! I know a bit, so if you ever need any help, just ask!”

Kaminari laughs and replies /IT’S SOFT TOO./Then Kirishima spots them, and for just a second Bakugou is about to declare Operate Silent Pikachu a success. But then he asks entirely the wrong question.
Bakugou waves his hand in front of Kaminari to regain his attention, then launches into rapidly if tediously fingerspelling /SHINSOU’S HAIR IS PURPLE./
Kaminari looks around the room and fingerspells /MINA, SERO, OJIRO/ as the doors to the common room open, and Kirishima returns with Uraraka, loaded down with shopping bags and munching mochi.
“I’m what?” Kaminari prompts.“Oh. Ahem. You’re actually good at this,” he says, signing it at the same time. “Try spelling out your friend’s names now, like you’re introducing them.”
“Huh.”“What?”“You’re uh…” Bakugou’s eyes flicker to the doors as he catches Kirishima’s hair approaching, and nerves flutter through his chest.

“You learn any of this before?” he asks.Kaminari shakes his head. “I’ve wanting to learn for a while since I have a hard time listening sometimes, and Shinsou said it’d be great on days when he has migraines, but I haven’t actually tried yet.”

To Bakugou’s surprise, Kaminari is a remarkably quick study. Two passes through the alphabet and he’s fingerspelling his name without much stalling. A third run and he catches most of what Bakugou spells out to quiz him.
Now all he has to do is make sure there’s a good reason to be signing when Kiri walks through those doors.
Ashido’s already sprawled across another couch watching videos on her phone, and there’s a TV in the common room.

It’s now because Kirishima left to go shopping an hour ago, but he told Ashido he’d be back in time for their favorite television program – which, after a little recon, Bakugou has learned starts in about twenty minutes.

Kaminari crawls back to his book, but then sits on the couch Bakugou dragged him too. “Okay, sure, now’s good I guess. But why now? And what’s wrong with /that/ couch?”“I can see the doors from this one. And now because I said so.”

“What’s the big idea?” Kaminari complains, grabbing for his book but finding it out of reach.Bakugou lets go of his ear to free his hands and explain in both languages at once. “You said you wanted to learn sign, right? First lesson starts now.”
“Oi! Dunce face! Get over here!”Kaminari drops his comic book as Bakugou grabs him by the ear and drags him from one common room couch to another.
That’s a whole other question that needs a whole other plan to answer, but Bakugou knows what to do about this one.It’s time to commence Operation Silent Pikachu.
Hm. Is that what they are?
But if he /doesn’t/ know… Bakugou’s stomach flips, trying not to get too attached to the idea of long conversations in silence with is best—
Bakugou decides the only way to settle this is to lay a trap. If Kirishima knows that /he/ knows sign, and hasn’t said anything about it yet, he’s got an AP Shot coming for his hard head.
@starry_stan Hell yeah it is

But has Kirishima ever seen? And if he has, why hasn’t he said anything yet?What the /hell?/

🤟🏽🤟🏽🤟🏽

Had he ever tried to sign anything to the redhead? Bakugou doesn’t think so. He’s certainly slipped with Jirou a couple of times when he was tired, using it out of habit the way he would around his family. Deku is a given.

But the mishap with the broken egg doesn’t hold a shadow of a candle to the new information about Kirishima. As Bakugou waits for his coffee to brew, he tries to run a mental tape of their interactions, looking for any clue that Kirishima was fucking /fluent in sign language./

He gives the floor another once-over with a damp towel and returns to his breakfast prep, more or less on autopilot. His hand hurts from the jagged bits of eggshell that were briefly embedded in it, but whatever. His mom’s salve is good for that.

It’s now dripping down his arm and onto the floor, and Bakugou yanks a towel from a drawer with his dry hand and squats down next to the puddle of raw egg and begins to busy himself with sopping up the mess.
An unpleasant poking sensation following by cold dripping brings Bakugou back to planet earth, and he realizes that in his brief stint as a blond statue, he had crushed the egg in his hand.
/What the fuck holy shit oh my god no way he when did he how does he what the FUCK?/

Bakugou freezes with the egg in his hand, jaw slack and eyes glazing over as he realizes that he hadn’t /heard/ Kirishima talking, he’d /seen/ Kirishima talking. As is in signing. Fluently. Expressively. With absolutely no hesitation.
He glances in the direction of the doors again, just to make sure he wasn’t imagining things, and—/Holy shit./

It’s six a.m., no one else is around, and Bakugou’s been out of bed for a whole eight minutes. His hearing aids are three floors above him, still plugged into the charger where he left them the night before. There’s no way in hell he should be able to hear Kirishima.
Wait just a minute.
Bakugou averts his eyes so as not to eavesdrop, and he’s about to crack an egg now that the pan is hot, but that’s when it dawns on him.
Except that he’s not. Kirishima is over by the door, chatting at warp speed with someone Bakugou hasn’t seen before, but appears to be related to him. Probably his mom.
It’s Sunday morning, everyone else is still asleep, and he’s milling about the common room kitchen making black coffee and an omelet, enjoying the calm while he’s the only one up.
The first time Bakugou sees it, it doesn’t even register at first.

Guess what folks? I liked this idea so much that I decided to write a little oneshot of it!

Canonverse, no significant cw’s, fluff!!

And the heat of the kiss Bakugou shut him up with made all the nerves and twists and turns in the road worth it.

♥︎♥︎♥︎
Kirishima returned the grin. “You know you wouldn’t have me any other way.”“Damn right.”
“Oh, yeah, any time,” said Kirishima. “I get it. Next time we’ll get you some sea bands or something.”Bakugou scoffed, but couldn’t hide the smile. “Sap.”
“I know what you did back there,” Bakugou said. “And thanks. That stop made the difference in me being able to hold on to my breakfast.”

At the summit, though, as Kirishima and Bakugou stood just close enough to a ledge to make Mama sweat and Bakugou grin at the thrill, Kirishima felt fingers lace through his, and he looked up to see an expression of gratitude in place of the feral smile.
No one said a word of any of it once the hike was underway, and under the gorgeous scenery and hot sun, the unpleasant drive was soon all but forgotten.
With both windows down, Bakugou spent the rest of the drive with his head on Kirishima’s shoulder, and a few miles before the trailhead, he even dozed off with his hand around Kiri’s.
“You boys ready to hit the road?” Mom asked. Kirishima looked sideways at Bakugou, who nodded. “Let’s motor!” Kirishima confirmed.

After a few more minutes, Bakugou turned and headed back towards the car, and Kirishima followed him. His moms had bought the forgotten sunscreen, along with a variety of snacks and a couple tacky tourist T-shirts.
“You want to try this?” Kirishima asked, offering him the protein bar.“Nah. Just the water.”“Alright. That’s fine. Just let me know when you want it.”“Mm.”
They stayed there a while in silence, with Bakugou slowly sipping the cold water Kirishima had brought him.

They took their time walking towards the viewpoint, but once they made it and looked out at the forested vista, a more peaceful expressed settled over Bakugou, one Kirishima was more used to seeing on their hiking trips.

Bakugou grumbled something under his breath at the same time he signed something, and Kirishima didn’t catch either one, but he was glad to see Bakugou taking his hand and stepping out of the car.“Good. It’s over here, come on!”

“Yeah, yeah, I know. Don’t want it now though.”“That’s fine,” said Kirishima. “Whenever you’re ready. There’s a nice little viewpoint over there behind the shop. Why don’t you come walk with me and get some air? We can take it slow.”
Kirishima held up the water bottles and protein bars he’d picked up. “Believe it or not, it helps to have at least something in your stomach.”
“Yeah. So does Todoroki. So relax. It’s no big deal. And besides, stressing out and beating yourself up about it is only going to make it worse.”
“You know any other sixteen year olds who still get fucking motion sickness?”“Uh. Yeah. Me.”Bakugou looked up. “Really?”
“How you feelin’?”“Like a damn idiot.”Kirishima frowned. “Why?”
Kirishima left Bakugou his space long enough to use the restroom and buy some drinks and snacks, then seeing his moms still perusing the aisles, returned to the car.
Kirishima didn’t really have to pee, but he figured he might as well while they were there. “You gonna be okay?” he asked as he climbed out of the back seat.“Mm. Go. I need to sit still.”
Once they were parked, Mama got out and gave Kirishima a pointed look. “We’re going to browse the gift shop for a bit. Why don’t you two use the facilities and stretch your legs a bit?”
Kirishima more or less held his breath until they reached the gift shop, keeping an eye on Bakugou and doing his best with the pressure points as they traversed the winding road.
“That’s a good idea,” she added, glancing down at her phone. “I could use a stretch. Looks like there’s a gift shop not far from here, and I think I forgot to pack sunscreen.”
“You know Mom, I really need to pee,” he said, going for broke. Mama turned around and met his eyes for a second, and Kirishima gave her a half-panicked look, and she nodded knowingly.

This all seemed to help for a while, but just as Kirishima thought Bakugou might fall asleep on his shoulder, the route of the road turned from gentle bends to something resembling spaghetti, and Kirishima could swear Bakugou was literally turning green.
Kirishima went a step further and picked up Bakugou’s hand, searching for the nausea pressure points Todoroki had showed him a while back.

Though she didn’t reply to his text, a moment later all four windows were open an inch or so, and a breeze of cool mountain air rushed into the car. Judging by the way Bakugou was breathing, he appreciated the fresh air.
/Can you get Mom to crack the windows? Bakugou’s not feeling good. But don’t say anything./

When they’d been quiet for a while and Bakugou seemed relatively comfortable with the position, but still breathing carefully and wiping his sweaty palms from time to time, Kirishima carefully extracted his phone to text Mama in the front passenger seat.
Fortunately, Bakugou got the memo well enough, and he hesitantly laid his head on Kirishima’s shoulder so he could look up front.

Bakugou was clearly straining to listen to him, and Kirishima felt a little guilty, hoping the added effort was a welcome distraction and not just making it worse. He would have gladly signed the whole conversation if he knew how, but he was nowhere near there yet.
“Put your head here so you can see out the front,” he said softly, trying not to let his moms hear. “Trust me. It’s better. The side window just makes it worse.”
Kirishima copied the movement, then nodded. “Okay. That makes sense I think. Come here.” He patted his right shoulder.Bakugou looked at him skeptically. “What?”
Bakugou gave him a barely perceptible nod. “And it’s like this,” he added, mimicking driving a car and then moving his open hands in front of his forehead and stomach.
Kirishima laughed off his nerves, then nodded. “Yeah, that. I always mess those letters up, dang it. Uh. So. Are you?”

Kirishima repeated the word, cringing as Bakugou watched impatiently while he signed at a sloth’s pace. Bakugou nodded in recognition when he finished, then signed it back to him much faster, with an emphasis on the fourth letter, /C-A-R-/S/-I-C-K./
Bakugou blinked, taken aback, then looked at Kirishima with his brows furrowed. Fortunately, he asked one of the few things Kirishima recognized. /Again?/

Kirishima decided to put his last few weeks of practicing in the mirror to use. Hoping he didn’t wildly screw it up, he took a deep breath of his own and raised his hands before slowly spelling out 
/C-A-R-E-I-C-K ?/
He didn’t sound angry, but his voice was unsteady, and he didn’t seem particularly happy to be speaking. /Yeah,/ Kirishima thought. /Sometimes you don’t even want to open your mouth…/
Kirishima reached across the middle seat to tap Bakugou’s wrist, and even this seemed to startle him.“Haah? What do you want?”
This he could handle.

A bizarre cocktail of sympathy and relief swept through Kirishima’s chest. Having suffered the same fate on plenty of road trips as a kid, he knew exactly what sort of misery Bakugou must be dealing with, but at least that was a known quantity, and it wasn’t his fault.
Bakugou wasn’t mad at him, and he probably wasn’t having an anxiety attack either.He was just /carsick./

Kirishima paid attention for another couple minutes, then when his head spun a little around a tightly banked hairpin turn at the same time Bakugou held his breath and clenched his teeth, he figured it out.
A couple minutes later, Bakugou took another series of metered breaths while wiping his palms on his knees, and Kirishima frowned. Whatever was bothering him, he must be terribly anxious.
Bakugou didn’t seem to notice that Kirishima was watching him, so he continued to watch him intently, hoping for a clue to what was going on and if there was anything he could do about it.
Kirishima’s mind began reeling, wondering if something had set off his anxiety, and if so, what it could be.

He’d almost distracted himself when he noticed the sound of Bakugou’s breathing had changed. Kirishima chanced a peek up, and saw Bakugou’s face set in intense focus, breathing slowly and methodically, similar to the way he did after nightmares.

They weren’t even halfway to the trailhead, so there would be several more hours of ice, it seemed. Kirishima sighed and flipped through old pictures on his phone, hoping to take his mind off his nebulous guilt.
@kaustikha THESE TEAMUPS omg

Maybe it had nothing to do with the plans. Maybe Kirishima had said something stupid on their way out, something to offend him perhaps. Again he tried to think of everything he’d said and came up blank. Everything had been fine. Totally fine.

So what the hell?

Maybe he wasn’t as comfortable going with Kirishima’s moms this time, instead of with his own family? They’d only met briefly… that could be it… but probably not, things had been going well enough before they’d set out.
Maybe Bakugou didn’t like this particular trail? Nah. He would have said so. Bakugou wasn’t one to tell white lies to make anyone happy.
So what could Kirishima have done wrong?
Their first two climbs together had been some of the most fun they’d ever had, even leading to a shy first kiss at the summit of the second hike.

At least three times, Kirishima had run over their conversations leading up to the trip in his head, trying to pick out any detail that would explain why Bakugou was freezing him out like this. Bakugou loved hiking.
It had been a whole hour since Bakugou had said so much as a word, and the last few he’d muttered before going silent at 2:57 had been curt at best.

♥︎♥︎♥︎

Kirishima was second-guessing… well, just about everything. He looked at the clock on his phone, then at Bakugou who was staring resolutely out the window, then back at the clock as it ticked over to 3:57.

A/N: I know in canonverse they should be using JSL and not ASL, but just as the narration and spoken dialogue is in English because that’s the only language I can write in, so too I gotta write their signed conversations in ASL. But I did want to acknowledge that difference!

And don’t be scared to speed-write a messy draft! It takes practice, but once you let go of the first draft being perfect, you can make a lot more progress. Sometimes I’ll mark a word or section [[like this]] to come back to later, and use the search function for those brackets!

20. Even if you feel nervous like I do about a subject, write the story you need to write. There’s an audience out there somewhere for just about everything, and even if you just write it for yourself, it’s still worth writing.

19. I struggle often with fearing the subject matter of my stories will make people think less of me. I put a lot of my soul in my writing and that’s a vulnerable thing!

On a more technical note… action scenes. Oof. I have NO idea what I’m doing with those!
18. Uh… yes, I definitely have words and sentence structures i overuse, but I’m not gonna tell you what they are. You’ll enjoy my writing much more without peeking behind that curtain!

17. Yes! I may have a couple stories without chapter titles, but most of them have them. Coming up with them is often one of the hardest parts, but I really like having the titles add sometime to the theme of the story if I can.

(My novel chapter titles are all song lyrics!)

16. I’m definitely a planner! It makes the actual writing a lot easier for me if I can look at an outline and know what scene is next. On some short oneshots though, I will just wing it. 

I also wrote the first like… 100K+ of my novel without planning, but it was unsustainable!
