15. Ideas spring to life from the void and beat me over the head until I write them!

If I AM trying to come up with something (such as for a zine application) I will start with the characters’ roles (e.g. paramedic!Kiri) and imagine what events would be interesting for them.

14. I LOVE some heavy angst as long as there’s hope. Angst with a happy ending (or at least hopeful) is highly cathartic and the superior story structure for me. MCD or other brutally sad endings are too painful for me 99% of the time.
13. Both! (But don’t worry, this account is still and will always be SFW.) I do enjoy each in their own respect. Just depends on what I’m up for in a given day.

12. InaTodo really squicks me for some reason, as do most Inasa ships actually. I think I just don’t find him attractive and the art turns me off.

I used to really dislike Endhawks too, but I’ve seen so much of it I’m kinda desensitized and it’s more of just disinterest now.

11. KRBK, obviously. I do multiship and enjoy other pairings, but at the end of the day Kiribaku will always be a cut above the rest for me.

Also Erasermic!! Aside from *maybe* an Aizawa/Ms. Joke fling, I don’t ship them with anyone else. Bonus points for Shinsou & Eri adoption.

10. Meh. I’ll read it if there are other elements of the story I’m interested in, but I don’t seek it out, and probably wouldn’t write it unless it was a commission. 

That said, Bakugou is an alpha and NOTHING anyone says is gonna change my mind!!

9. Hurt/comfort alllll the way baby. Bonus points if it’s a very specific brand of hurt/comfort in which the tough or stoic character is forced to be soft and vulnerable and accept help. CHEF’S KISS. (Have I written Bakugou like this repeatedly? Yes. Will I continue? Also yes.)

8. Mostly in-character, but I’m not afraid to push that boundary a little bit. Especially in an AU and/or an aged-up scenario where there’s been a lot of chance for growth and change, I like to explore how characters think and behave a little outside what we see in canon.
7. Yea! Most of my writing is for more popular ships, but I’m all in favor of rare pairs! And I’m glad to call myself one of the few, the proud, the writers of OFA2/3.
@Veewritesalot AHAHA yep Pokemon 😆
6. Both. The short fics are usually oneshots and the long ones usually get broken into chapters.

5. If I have a sudden brainworm that I write impulsively, it’s likely to be a 1-3K oneshot. But if it’s a fic I’ve planned and outlined, they tend to be around 20K +/-

…and then there was Red Rises which I thought would be 15-20K and was over 75. 🙃

4. Past tense all the way. I almost never write in present tense. (It might be a good exercise to try a short thread that way, in fact…) BUT I’m not above taking a little poetic license and using “now” and “here” in the narration of an otherwise past tense fic.

3. I wrote my whole first novel and all its offshoots in first person, but the second novel and most if not all of my fanfiction is in third person. I definitely prefer third person now, and it’s always a bit jarring when I go back to that first novel!

2. Depends again! Threads I will just yeet into the void with little more than a quick proofread (if that, tbh…) and some oneshots or fics where I know it’s a smaller audience, I won’t bother having them beta read. But usually if taking a thread to AO3, I’ll get a beta then.

1. Depends! Often there’s a specific song that fits the vibe of what I’m writing, or might even be referenced in a scene, and then I’ll listen to it on repeat. (For example, the Terrible Things scene in my high school AU.) Otherwise, quiet for writing is good too.

He stood tall as he slid out of bed, then opened the side of the closet with the special things of Haruka’s he’d kept. With a deep breath, he unclasped the chain around his neck, kissed the ring, and hung it next to the one that held the Haruka’s.

Though the dream had nothing to do with his earlier monologue with her empty space, he knew when he woke up that she would want him to be happy, and that Eijirou had her blessing to find happiness amongst the living.
Eijirou’s dreams were peaceful after that. He dreamed of Haruka, but it didn’t hurt this time.
like the little things that brought them joy in the dark, or what they the imagined Shizuko might learn to do next. Finally, at almost four, they hung up and fell asleep.
For over an hour, until Eijirou was so sleepy he kept dropping the phone, he and Katsuki talked, first about the hard things like recovering from their losses, and slowly about other things,

“I bet…” said Eijirou, imagining the scene Katsuki had once described of the raid on his base that had ended in so many casualties. “Well… I’m sure glad we have you for support.”“Yeah,” Katsuki assured him. “You do.”

Eijirou told Katsuki how he’d done his best to explain Haruka’s absence, and what he’d learned about Shizuko’s limited memory of it all.”“Good,” said Katsuki. “It’s better she doesn’t remember it. Sometimes I wish I didn’t remember.”
“Mine connect to my phone with bluetooth. I can hear you fine.”“Right. Okay. So uh… yeah. I’m a wreck.”“That’s okay. Death’s a hard topic. Especially for a kid. How did it go?”
Heh. I haven’t exactly had a lot of late night phone calls in the last few years, don’t know what I was thinking. Habit, I guess.”

Eijirou laughed sheepishly. “I was gonna ask if you can hear me okay on the phone since I have to talk quietly while Shizuko’s asleep, but that means she’s not wearing her hearing aids, and I assume you are.
“Are you okay?” he asked as soon as Eijirou answered the phone.“Uh… a little better /now,/” said Eijirou,  “Can you—oh, never mind.”“What?”

The three dots appeared and disappeared a few times, then Eijirou jumped when he realized Katsuki was actually calling him.
/Hard day. Hard night. Talked to Shizuko about her mom today. She took it better than I thought, but I’m still shaken up about it./
Eijirou blinked, then smiled as the instant endorphins from the much-needed human contact flooded through his aching veins.
But then, to his surprise, a reply came./Yes. Can’t sleep. Why are YOU awake?/

Eijirou chided himself as he set the phone down. There was no reason for Katsuki to be awake at that hour. He cringed, hoping his teacher slept with his phone on Do Not Disturb. Otherwise, he was likely in for a few choice words in the morning.
It was two in the morning, but Eijirou found himself reaching for his phone./Are you awake?/

It hurt. It hurt from inside, outside, in joints Eijirou didn’t know he had; it hurt like being buried alive and yet like he might explode. The gold ring felt heavy in his hands, and the pending decision even heavier on his heart.
Eijirou sat up, running his finger and thumb over the wedding ring that hung against his chest. He looked again at the empty pillow where Haruka had once rested her lovely head. /Is it time?/
But the room was empty save for him, the only sound the gentle whirr of the heater and the occasional car driving by.
/It’s okay./Eijirou snapped his head up, certain he’d heard his wife’s voice, as loud and clear as the song on the radio.“Ha- Haruka?”
It felt right. So… if it’s okay… god, I don’t know how to do this. How do I do this? I can’t let you go. I can’t. But maybe…”
But I felt it, Haruka, that feeling I felt when I fell in love with you. I felt it sitting next to him. And I’m so lonely without you. It felt good to feel that again.

“And… um… if you’re out there… there’s something I want you to know. I met someone. Someone who’s been… well, I think he might bring my sunshine back. It feels weird, you know. Liking someone else, when I’m still married to you and I miss you with every beat of my heart.
“But I’m trying. We talked about you today. She doesn’t really remember you, but I think she remembers your love. She said you were pretty. She was sure right about that.

“I miss you so much,” he whispered to the empty space in the bed beside him. “Every single day. It just kills me that Shizuko has to grow up without you. You were such a good mom. I don’t know what the heck I’m doing.
Later that night, even though he’d only heard the first few notes, Eijirou couldn’t get Haruka’s favorite song out of his head.

And it was another relief to know for sure what Shizuko did and didn’t remember. He took a bite of the taco anyway, hopeful if still intensely emotional.

Eijirou had entirely forgotten his appetite, but he was relieved to have that dreaded conversation behind him. It had been far more difficult for him than for Shizuko, but that was the way he wanted it.
“She does,” said Shizuko with a confidence Eijirou could only dream about. Satisfied with the simplified explanation of death, Shizuko reached into the bag and handed Eijirou a taco. “Hungry?”
Eijirou laughed a little through the tears. “I hope so. I bet she will. She had two years of looking at /you/ first. I don’t think she could have any bad dreams if you’re the last thing she saw.”
“You sure she never wake up?”“Yeah, baby, I’m sure. She’s gone.”Shizuko thought about this for a moment, picking at the Velcro on her shoe. “Do she have good dreams?”

Shizuko looked up at his eyes, her own filled with a worldly sadness that had no place on the face of a child. “So she asleep forever?”“Yeah, that’s right.” Eijirou choked back tears. “Mom’s asleep forever.”

“Okay… well… sometimes when people get hurt really badly – and I mean /really/ badly, they don’t get better. They… it’s sort of like they go to sleep. But forever. You got hurt a little bit that day, in the explosion. But Mom got hurt really badly.”
“Alright. So. Do you remember the accident? They day you got your scar? And the day you lost your hearing?”Shizuko shook her head. “Sometimes… I have dreams. Maybe that. I don’t know.”
“Okay,” Shizuko nodded. “You strong, Daddy. Iss okay.”/She’s the strong one./

“Oh boy. This is hard. This is going to be hard for both of us, okay?” Eijirou was shaking, glad for the support of his car behind him, and in disbelief that he was about to have this conversation on the pavement of a Taco Bell parking lot, but there was no way around it.

Her one word knocked whatever air was left in Eijirou’s lungs into oblivion. “I—you—do you remember her?”
Shizuko tilted her head to the side. “Why? It nice song.”“Oh, uh… it reminds me of someone I miss every day. So it makes me sad.”Shizuko nodded matter-of-factly. “Mom.”
“That song…” his voice cracked. “It’s hard for me to listen to.”

As he summoned the courage to pull himself together, a deeply confused Shizuko appeared in front of him, paper bag in hand.“What you doing?” she asked him. “You forget food.”
pounding heart crushing his lungs and the sound of Haruka singing along echoing in his head.

When Eijirou came back with the hot bowls of soup, he nearly melted into the floor at the sight of his daughter lying with her head in Katsuki’s lap, cozy red blanket around her shoulders and a contented look on her face.

Eijirou took Katsuki’s bag so he could take off his boots, and while he set it in the kitchen, Katsuki went straight to Shizuko and asked how she was feeling, giving her a chance to vent about her discomfort.
Eijirou laughed, wondering how many other lessons Katsuki had rescheduled or cancelled to have time to go home and make soup on a moment’s notice. “Come on in, then, it’s cold out there!”

Katsuki shrugged. “It probably isn’t. And if it is, whatever. I got a tough immune system. And I brought her some soup. Since she liked my cooking, I thought some spicy soup would do wonders for her head. And maybe you can get some practice.”
“You sure you want to be here? I don’t really know if this thing’s contagious, but she’s running quite a fever. If it is, she’s probably gonna take me down with her sooner or later…”
“Miserable,” said Eijirou, nodding to where Shizuko had been pouting on the couch, but her face lit up once she saw Katsuki.
“Oh—hi! What are you doing here?”“I got your message,” he said. “How is she?”

Midway through some cartoon he didn’t recognize, Eijirou had almost dozed off when there was a knock on the door. He carefully extricated himself from a clingy Shizuko long enough to answer the door, and was surprised to see Katsuki.
Shizuko was cranky and uncomfortable, and Eijirou gave up on trying to get any work done before he started, opting instead to snuggle on the couch and try to make his daughter comfortable.
It went to voicemail, so Eijirou left him a quick explanation, then picked up the antibiotics and went home.

A mercifully quick trip to the pediatrician – their first stroke of luck in weeks – confirmed that Shizuko had an ear infection, and Eijirou called Katsuki from the line at the drive-through pharmacy to cancel their sign language lesson for that afternoon.

With the cold weather, Eijirou hadn’t thought anything of the runny nose Shizuko had had the last few days, but with her little body radiating heat in his arms, he was actually a little relieved for an explanation for her sudden change in behavior.

Shizuko covered her ears and nuzzled her forehead against Eijirou’s chest, and then it made sense. She was warm. “Okay, okay,” said Eijirou calmly, setting aside the hearing aids and pulling her closer so she could feel the soothing vibration of his voice. “I get it.”
Eijirou frowned, wondering why the sudden change. /It hurts? Where?/
/It hurts,/ Shizuko complained in sign, shaking her head at Eijirou’s latest attempt to get the hearing aids back on her.

Months of progress dissolved before Eijirou’s eyes as she simply refused to keep them on, crying and fussing and ripping them off if he tried to put them back on, and Eijirou was ready to tear his hair out wondering what on earth the problem was.
And of course, just as the snow had finally melted and the new dryer had finally been delivered and installed, Shizuko suddenly stopped wanting to wear her hearing aids again.

Thanks again for all the support over the past year! I look forward to all our coming adventures in 2022!! 💕💕💕

Beyond that, there’s a possibility of other bang and/or zine pieces, and I definitely want to get some of this year’s threads beta read, revised, and posted to AO3, so hopefully I’ll build that portfolio up more this coming year.
In between all this, I’ll be adding intermittent updates to my Erasermic college AU (AO3 only, but SFW)

In the summer, I will finally bring back the interactive Baywatch AU. The one where Everyone Lives, Including People Canonically Dead. This should be a fun-in-the-sun break from the angst for summer ☀️🌊🏄🏼‍♂️

If all goes as planned, the college sequel to this year’s high school AU will launch on the one year anniversary of the ending of the original - March 29th! I’m REALLY excited to return to this universe!!!
In early March, I’ll be posting the @krbkizch Parallels piece I’ve been working on! This is gonna be a tooth-rottingly wholesome good time.

Then the first couple months will be devoted to Partly Cloudy with a Chance of Explosions, my beloved single dad AU. January updates might be a little sparse during my busy work season, but I’ll do as much as I can.

I’ll be kicking off the year with posting an up-till-now exclusive piece to AO3! This one is for the 18+ crowd and I really pushed myself to try a style I hadn’t done much of, and I’m really excited to share it with the world!

And that’s a wrap on my threads for 2021!!!

And what a year it’s been, wow. Thanks for everyone who came along for the ride! 

Below is a little peek at what I have in store for the coming year… 👀

“Yeah,” he said with a hint of his usual smile tugging at his mouth. “It will. And even if she can’t bring my quirk back, I’m gonna be alright. You and Midoriya both told me that, and today proved it.”Bakugou grinned. “I never doubted you.”

“Behaving as it should. The drugs have worn off. She’s just dehydrated and sleep-deprived. Give her a couple days to recover and she should be able to restore your quirk.”Bakugou gave Kirishima’s shoulder a playful shove. “Told ya it’d all work out.”

“You two didn’t have to wait all this time. They’re going to be fine.”“Glad to hear it,” said Kirishima, exhaling and feeling a great deal of tension leave his body. “Any news on how Eri’s quirk is doing?”
In the hospital waiting room a few hours later, Aizawa came back from checking on Mic and Eri, bearing steaming cups of hot chocolate for Bakugou and Kirishima.

Granted, they hadn’t run into any more trouble than a few mosquitos and the occasional rough patch of trail, but it felt good to have accomplished a mission, even without his quirk. It was an easy win, but a win all the same.
It was a long trek back to civilization with the addition of two injured and exhausted party members, but Kirishima was more than happy to carry Eri on his back the whole way to the city.
“That’s alright, Eri,” Aizawa assured her. “We’ll get you both taken care of. When you’ve had some food and rest, we can evaluate your quirk’s stability.”
Eri nodded her agreement. “I don’t feel so strange anymore, but I’m tired and hungry. We decided it was best not to push our luck, even though he’s hurt. I didn’t want to make it worse by accident.”

Mic gritted his teeth at the pain in his leg. “I don’t think they took her age or size into consideration when they doped us up on those quirk suppressants. I think she’ll be okay, but they gave her a bit much for a twelve-year-old.”

“That’s a bad break,” Aizawa frowned, taping Mic’s clearly broken leg into a makeshift splint with bandages and downed branches. “Can Eri not heal you?”“We didn’t want to risk it,” Eri piped up, rubbing her eyes. “I’m sorry. I’m still so tired and out of it.”
Aizawa and Shinsou hugged them both, checking them for injuries and wrapping them in emergency blankets.

Deep in the forest, past lightning-scarred pines and swampy patches where the trails disappeared into moss and mud, Earphone Jack located Mic and Eri huddled up for warmth inside the base of a hollow tree.
“Let’s find out!” said Kirishima, knocking his fists together. It didn’t make the same signature clank he was used to without his quirk, but it was encouraging nonetheless.

“She and Mic were both put on quirk suppressants when we were captured. I believe the drug they were using for that is a more established one than the boosters they tested on me, the sort the police use to subdue prisoners, but I’m not certain.”
Kirishima swallowed. “Why would her quirk be compromised?”
I don’t want to make any promises, but bringing you back to a state with your quirk intact should be well within her capabilities if /her/ quirk hasn’t been compromised.”

“Well, it wasn’t you. And I’m kind of glad. I’m… this is gonna take some getting used to, but you know what? I’m gonna be okay.”

Being reminded that he was still himself, with or without it, he felt much less stripped of his sense of self.

Long after Midoriya had gone home, Kirishima was repeating those words to himself. Though he still wasn’t sure what he was going to /do/ if his quirk was really gone forever, there was time to figure that out.

And so are you. Your quirk isn’t what makes you special. You’re still an admirable person and a good soul, even if you never get your quirk back. Anyone who knows you is going to see that. Your chivalry speaks much louder than your quirk ever will.”

“You know,” said Midoriya. “All Might taught me something pretty important back then. It wasn’t my body or my combat ability or anything else like that that made an impression on him. And quirk or not, I’m the same person I always was.

“That means a lot,” said Kirishima, savoring a particularly tender piece of pork. “Man. I guess you know better than anyone how I feel now. I don’t think I really know anyone else who is or was quirkless.”

I’m sure the police will have samples of the drugs they used on Aizawa, and we should be able to get some better intel on how they work. If there’s a way to get your quirk back, we’re going to find it!”

Kirishima’s heart sank as Midoriya rambled on. He’d often felt behind his peers even /with/ a quirk.
But—oh no, this must not be cheering you up at all, I’m so sorry, I—I’m sure you’ll figure this out! You already have lots of practical training that I didn’t have back then, and—”
“Oh! I… well… lonely,” said Midoriya. “I never really felt like I fit in anywhere, like I was as good as my friends, or… like I’d ever get where I wanted.
“What was it like, being quirkless?” he blurted out suddenly.

Kirishima hadn’t eaten much since the accident, but he certainly felt a little more like himself as he tucked into the hearty homemade food. Still, he’d been trying about once every hour to activate his quirk, all with no success.

Kirishima glanced at the Crimson Riot nightlight and wiped away his tears. /My spirit’s taken a pretty big hit now that my quirk’s been erased.//Yeah. And? I know you, Eiji. You can take the hit. You’re strong. Uneraseably strong./

⚙️❤️‍🩹⚙️

/I don’t understand.//You. Don’t. Break./ Bakugou emphasized each word by stopping his hands sharply, as if each sign were a punch he needed to land. /And I don’t just mean your quirk. I mean your spirit. Your MANLY spirit./
/That’s not gonna happen.//What makes you so sure?/ Kirishima wanted to know./YOU./

/What if I have to start over?/ he asked with shaking hands. /What if I never get my quirk back and I have to be a…/ he dropped his hands into his lap, having no idea how to finish that sentence. Firefighter? Gym teacher? Grocery store clerk?

Kirishima hadn’t realized he was crying until he felt the tears soak though the flannel of his pajama pants as they fell. If even something as natural as /breathing/ took this much work, how was he ever going to relearn life without his quirk?

/A little,/ he responded. /But pain I can handle. I’m scared. I can’t breathe./Bakugou placed a palm on Kirishima’s chest and watched for a few moments as it rose and fell in shallow, trembling breaths./Yes you can./

Kirishima blinked, sucking in a breath and trying to come back into his body from… wherever the hell he’d just been. His chest ached, but he was sure that had more to do with the panic attack than the injury. The cut stung, but it was tolerable.
/What’s wrong?/ Bakugou asked him in sign. /Are you in pain?/
Kirishima didn’t realize he had sat down on the floor until he felt a tap on his wrist and looked up to see Bakugou’s face illuminated by the glow of the little Crimson Riot nightlight.
It didn’t help much, but at least the air was cold, cooling the burning hot fear that engulfed his entire body and consumed all the oxygen in his lungs.
His vision was rapidly fading to gray as he staggered through the hall, trying to find the nearest window. There was a small one in the bathroom.
Choking on his own pounding heartbeat, Kirishima stumbled over his feet looking for a window. Air, /air,/ how could there be no air in this hallway?

Aizawa had no idea how long the effect would last. It could be a few hours, a few days, or perhaps the rest of his life. As the afternoon had worn on and Kirishima hadn’t been able to harden so much as a fingertip, he grew increasingly resigned to the worst case scenario.
Now, suddenly, he was twenty-two and quirkless.
Sure, he’d faltered now and then during high school when he feared he was getting behind his peers, but he’d never /really/ sorted out what he would do if he wasn’t a hero.
The weight of this epiphany was crushing, and Kirishima yanked at his shirt, struggling to breathe. There had never been a plan B.

Every moment of doubt he’d ever had that his quirk wasn’t strong enough, wasn’t flashy enough, wasn’t /cool/ enough crashed down over his shoulders with the cruelty of its likeness to death; a sudden loss of a part of himself he’d never prepared to say goodbye to.
Never had it occurred to him that there might come a day when he wouldn’t have it anymore. Getting his quirk was supposed to be like getting taller, he was never supposed to /shrink/.
/You don’t know what you’ve got till it’s gone,/ Kirishima thought miserably as he considered that he’d give almost anything to feel his hardened knuckle break the skin over his eye again now.
It seemed so ironic that he’d resented that quirk at the time, when in the same blink-of-an-eye that his quirk had appeared, so too it had disappeared.

Surely he’d rubbed his eyes sleepily countless times since that night, and he didn’t think of it often, but this time he was poignantly reminded of the exact moment he had gone from quirkless to /Kirishima Eijirou – quirk: hardening./

Yawning and rubbing his eyes on the way to the bathroom at two a.m., Kirishima’s knuckle brushed the scar over his eye, and he froze in his tracks at the sudden memory of the time he had done the exact same thing as a small child and created that scar.
